summary: The West African Court of Appeal dismissed an appeal in J. J. Ocquaye v. L. Quarshie & Ors. (1937) because the appellant failed to pay costs awarded by a Native Tribunal and did not obtain proper leave to appeal. The court held that the Provincial Commissioner's Court lacked authority under section 77(2) of the Native Administration Ordinance to grant leave, and the proviso did not empower the appellate court to intervene. In a separate case, Mensah Nyaku & Ors. v. Otoo Pabi, the court allowed an appeal challenging the joinder of parties and causes of action, ruling that combining a land ownership claim—within the jurisdiction of a Native Tribunal—with claims involving interpretation of English-form legal documents created procedural unfairness. The writ was struck out without prejudice to re-filing in appropriate forums.
verdict: Appeal dismissed in Ocquaye; appeal allowed in Nyaku
rationaleHighlights: Provincial Commissioner's Court lacks power to grant leave to appeal under section 77(2)
Proviso does not empower appellate court to grant leave to lower tribunal
Joinder of land ownership claim with document interpretation claims causes procedural embarrassment
Fair trial impossible due to mixed jurisdictional claims
Order 3 Rule 8 permits striking out improperly joined claims
Native Tribunals have primary jurisdiction over land ownership
Writ struck out without prejudice to refiling in proper courts
Costs awarded to successful appellants in Nyaku case
